    Hints and Hauls thread for Sour, Saison, and Funk Round 16! Post hints for your sender and target; along with general shenanigans.

    The rules:

    A box filled with lambic, wild ales, berliners, saisons, farmhouse ales, goses, etc., as well as anything else that is rustic or funky.
    • A 6 bottle shipper*
    • All beers must be an rAvg of 4.0 or higher or a 'want' by your target.**
    • Try to find fun and exciting bottles/growlers that your target otherwise wouldn't likely be able to try
    • Quantity is good, quality is better!
    * ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
    **If you can't hit wants, please try to find fun stuff that your target otherwise wouldn't likely be able to try.

    Shipping deadline: Monday, May 13

    If you squint, you can see that this is the BA version....I'm kind of torn as to whether I like it better or not than regular.

    I do like the flavor that the red wine barrel adds, also the blending/mellowing of the base flavors after a year in the puncheon.

    However, (caveat: I have a baby palate and vocabulary when speaking seriously about this stuff), there was a lingering what I think of as "tannic" perception that I get when drinking red wine (which I don't very often) that hit/stayed on the back of the tongue that is not my favorite thing about drinking wine.

    YMMV, especially if you are a wine fan.

    Sorry for the delay, things came up at work and I got stuck much later than expected. Unflattering garage pics because these are all going straight in the fridge. box_social got me good w this box including some of my favorite funky breweries.

    https://i.imgur.com/NR9pu61_d.jpg?maxwidth=640&shape=thumb&fidelity=medium

    The de gawde bottles. Very excited since I haven’t had anything from them in awhile. A nice sante blend collab, gin BA nectarine banger, blended spontaneous ale (love their spontaneous blends so looking forward to this one!!) and raspberry spruce tip SP collab. No misses here, and I’ll be sure to chill the Long Tooth for a good amount of time before opening!

    https://i.imgur.com/nvlovpR_d.jpg?maxwidth=640&shape=thumb&fidelity=medium

    Next is the Upright goods. Not pictured is the BA wit growler which was crushed at work. I would not have guessed Pinot barrels but definitely got nice light vanilla oakiness to it. Overall it was fantastic and paired great with takis and secret aardvark. There’s a Dutch-inspired vermouth BA beer , anni saison which is a blend of open fermented cask aged saisons, and a saison aged in casks with gewürztraminer grapes (love anything with grapes so this is a hit!!). Upright is one of my favorite breweries in general and I have not had any of these before.

    https://i.imgur.com/jxPMtCm_d.jpg?maxwidth=640&shape=thumb&fidelity=medium

    And a nice mix of small format! My favorite geueze and a bottling date which I haven’t had before. The gigantic brew is a sour ale with orange and lemon aged in gin barrels (can’t get enough of the gin BA funk). And some block 15 treats! I haven’t had matryoshka in a few years but absolutely love this beer so it’s a very nice addition to this box. Can’t wait to try this dg collab though, was intrigued since I heard about it. Block 15 saison blended with de garde spontaneous beer sounds delightful. box_social i can’t thank you enough for an awesome selection of Oregon funk. Again these are some of my favorite breweries and I’m really looking forward to drinking my way through these over the next few weeks. None to be had tonight (other than the crowler) but I’ll be digging in this weekend. If you happen to need a sante proxy at any point just let me know!

    Nice box!

    ccbstl said: > ↑ >
    >
    Isn't it weird the "fridge" has a d but refrigerator doesn't?
    >
     

    Artificial refrigeration was first demonstrated by William Cullen in 1748, and the earliest refrigeration machines developed in the first half of the 19th century. But the word refrigerator is much older; it dates to the early 1600s, and refrigerate, from the Latin verb refrigerare and ultimately from the adjective frigus, meaning "cold," dates to the preceding century. Frigus also gave us our adjective frigid.

    (It should be noted that, as is consistent with Latin words, frigus and refrigerare were each pronounced with a hard g--that is, like the g in good. The shift to a soft-g sound—that is, pronounced like the g in gesture--in frigid and refrigerate didn't occur until both words were established in English and at the mercy of French pronunciation influences.)

    As refrigerators became common in households, it was only natural for a colloquial form of the word refrigerator to drop into the vernacular.

    So how did we arrive at the altered spelling?

    As with many abbreviated forms, it is very likely that fridge was popular in spoken English for a long time before it was used in print with any regularity. Writers deciding how to spell the word likely wanted a spelling that replicated how the word was pronounced. Simply cutting the word to the letters in its second syllable, frig, may have been undesirable since most words ending in the consonant g are pronounced with a hard-g sound: mug, beg, pig, etc.

    Since the word pronounced as \FRIJ\ ended in a \j\ sound, English speakers likely opted to spell it to follow the pattern of other familiar English words that end in a \j\ sound: judge, bridge, lodge, etc. Many of these words were borrowed from Middle English, where they had been originally spelled with a double-g (juggen, briggen, etc.); the switch to -dg- might have been influenced by Old French spellings. It is not unusual for clipped words to see new letters introduced into their spellings, as in perk for percolate or tater as a dialectical spelling of potato.

    The short form frig does continue to exist as a lesser-used variant spelling of fridge:
